article.description: Michael Jordan scored 23 points, and Richard Hamilton had 21 in his first start in six weeks as the Washington Wizards finally beat the Indiana Pacers 109-89 Sunday.

article.headline: Hamilton adds 21 points as Wiz solve Pacers

images.name: Rose_Jalen 020203 inline
images.caption: Michael Jordan has words with Jalen Rose during the fourth quarter. Both players were called for techical fouls; Rose was ejected because it was his second.

article.linkText: Jordan helps Wizards snap out of Pacers' spell
article.story:
WASHINGTON (AP) -- After a bit of bumping and shoving, Michael Jordan gave Jalen Rose an elbow to the chest and eventually got free for a layup. As Jordan turned to go downcourt, Rose led with his shoulder and gave Jordan a jarring blow. A few seconds and several choice words later, Jordan had a technical and Rose was ejected from the game. Though he now wears a different uniform, Jordan still represents a ton of emotional baggage for Indiana Pacers. It boiled over again in the Washington Wizards' 109-89 victory Sunday. "Michael had a great rivalry with those guys when Indiana and Chicago used to play each other in the playoffs, so there's a little chippiness going on," said Washington coach Doug Collins, who went on the court to restrain Jordan after the confrontation with Rose. "I don't think Reggie (Miller) and the Indiana team view Michael as playing for the Wizards. I think they just see Michael and remember all the battles they had." The most painful memory for Pacers fans was the Bulls' seven-game series victory in the Eastern Conference finals in 1998, Jordan's last season before his second retirement. The Pacers beat the Wizards twice earlier this season: on Thanksgiving Day, and by holding Jordan to a career-low six points in a 108-81 victory on Dec. 27. "We've had some physical battles over the year with Indiana," Jordan said. "And today, because of the nature of the game, it kind of got out of hand." Jordan scored 23 points on 11-for-19 shooting in 41 minutes. Richard Hamilton, in his first start since Dec. 21, had 21 points for the Wizards, who have won five of six. Hamilton missed 17 games with a groin tear and came off the bench the last two games. Indiana's offensive star was Rose, who had 22 of his 27 points in the second half as the Pacers spent the entire game playing catch-up. His ejection ended any hopes for a comeback victory. Rose got his first technical for taunting Hamilton after a dunk in the final seconds of the third quarter. Then Rose and Jordan got double technicals as they jawed while running down the court after their elbow-shoulder battle. The Pacers were trailing by 14 with 4:11 to play. "He probably was tired of me trying to be in his face all day, just like I was tired of him trying to score on me," Rose said. "He wasn't going to back down. I wasn't going to back down. ... I got to find a way to keep my composure. In the heat of the battle, you do and say things that you regret." The victory was a big one in early playoff maneuvering, with both teams entering Sunday two games over .500 and riding two-game winning streaks. Also, the Wizards had lost six straight and 15 of 16 to the Pacers, and Indiana's sense of bravado in the first two games this season made for easy motivation. "In the locker room before the game, we said remember what happened," Washington's Tyrone Nesby said. "And we weren't going to let it happen again." The Wizards, who made three starting lineup changes from their previous game, never trailed and took control with an 18-2 run that included four 3-pointers and points from five different players late in the third quarter. Besides Hamilton, the other two changes in the Wizards lineup produced one double-double and nearly another. Nesby, starting for Popeye Jones to add some youth against the athletic Pacers, had 10 points and a season-high 10 rebounds. Jahidi White, back after serving a one-game suspension, had three of the Wizards' first seven baskets and finished with 10 points and nine rebounds. The Wizards shot 52 percent, the Pacers 48 percent, but the Pacers were hurt by long cold spells. Washington outrebounded Indiana 43-32 and had a 28-8 edge in second-chance points. The Wizards shot 64 percent in the first quarter to take a 31-25 lead, and the Pacers missed nine straight shots during an 8-0 Wizards run that made it 43-29 in the second quarter. Game notes
Jordan twisted his right ankle late in the game, but he said he was fine. ... Indiana's Jermaine O'Neal sprained his left ankle when he landed awkwardly after making a hook shot with 5:47 remaining. Thomas said O'Neal's ankle will be evaluated Tuesday.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
